titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Travelers in the Middle East collection of travel guides, narratives and images, circa 1852-2004 MS 585
titlestmt.author: Mary Tobin / Amanda Focke

publicationstmt.publisher: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

note.p: Stored off-site at the Library Service Center. Please request this material via woodson@rice.edu or call 713-348-2586.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-04-01 23:16:05 -0500.

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.unittitle: Travelers in the Middle East collection of travel guides, narratives and images
did.abstract: This collection consists of the physical materials that are represented digitally in the Travelers in the Middle East Archive (TIMEA), a collection created to make possible the study of Western interactions with the Middle East, particularly travel to Egypt in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The materials are of diverse types: images in the forms of post cards, photographs, and stereograph films; articles, pamphlets, and travel guidebooks; maps, and souvenirs.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Travelers in the Middle East Archive (TIMEA) is an archive of materials that reflect Western interactions with the Middle East, particularly Egypt, during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. This collection is composed of physical items in the archive apart from illustrations and photographs in books that are referenced in the related digital project, which is online at timea.rice.edu. These physical items are a variety of formats, including travel guides, museum catalogs, travel narratives; post cards and stereographic views of monuments, street scenes, people, and events; maps; pamphlets; souvenir programs; and souvenir objects.

The collection was assembled by Dr. Paula Sanders, Professor of History at Rice University. Many of the items were acquired over the period of time she prepared to write Creating Medieval Cairo: Empire, religion, and architectural preservation in nineteenth-century Egypt (American University in Cairo Press, 2008). Her gathering of items began when she was Scholar in Residence at the American Research Center in Egypt in 1995-96.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the physical materials that are represented digitally in the Travelers in the Middle East Archive (TIMEA), a collection created to make possible the study of Western interactions with the Middle East, particularly travel to Egypt in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The materials are of diverse types: images in the forms of post cards, photographs, and stereograph films; articles, pamphlets, and travel guidebooks; maps, and souvenirs.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This material is open for research.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Stored off-site at the Library Service Center. Please request this material via woodson@rice.edu or call 713-348-2586.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Dr. Paula Sanders, January 2016.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Travelers in the Middle East Archive (TIMEA) Collection, MS 585, Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Published books donated as part of this collection have been cataloged separately in the Woodson's rare book collection, stored off-site at the Library Service Center. These books can be identified by having the following note: "Donated by Paula Sanders. This text is part of the Travelers in the Middle East Archive (TIMEA), funded by the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS), and the Computer and Information Technology Institute (CITi), Rice University."
See also: Sanders, Paula. Creating Medieval Cairo: Empire, religion, and architectural preservation in nineteenth-century Egypt.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: This collection of physical materials is to some some degree represented online by the Travelers in the Middle East project (TIMEA) located at http://timea.rice.edu/. The Travelers in the Middle East Archive (TIMEA) is a digital archive that focuses on Western interactions with the Middle East, particularly travels to Egypt during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. TIMEA offers electronic texts such as travel guides, museum catalogs, and travel narratives, photographic and hand-drawn images of Egypt, and historical maps of Egypt and Cyprus. In addition, TIMEA provides educational modules that set the materials in context and explore how to conduct historical research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from the Travelers in the Middle East Archive (TIMEA) Collection must be obtained through the Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library.

did.unittitle: Series I: Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of 144 items in addition to a 36-page leather-bound album with pages filled with small black and white prints. Of these there is random labeling, e.g. "Heliopolis," "on the Nile," "modern Cairo" (with automobile resembling 1930's design). 41 of the loose photographs are approximately 5"x7" and contain images of buildings, architectural details, statues, and a few people. 70 are approximately 4"x6", also images of buildings, decorative elements, and people. There are 4 photocards of items at the Mus√©e de Boulaq. From a set labeled "20 Cairo Snaps," there are 6 labeled 2"x3"black and white photos. Finally, there are 23 of a 25-photocard set titled Monuments Chois√©s de Mus√©e de Boulaq" with Texte Explicatif dated 1881.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook of street scenes and people, Heliopolis, Egypt
Cairo snapshots (professional printed with numbers and place names on the reverse, in a red envelope identifying "Publ. A. Copyr, by Lehnart & Landrock, Succs. Series 302" - 6 b/w images, 2" x 3.5"

Monuments Choisis du Musee de Boulaq (Egypt), Collection de 25 photographies avec texts explicatif par Emile Brugsch, Conservateur Adj. du Musee (23 prints included here, plus descriptive text pamphlet), 1881
Photo cards from Musee de Boulaq (Egypt), 4 prints mounted on yellow cards, by E. Edwards
Snapshots of street scenes, building details and people, some identified, various sizes 5x7" and smaller
Color postcards / advertisements
Series II: Stereographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In addition to 118 stereographs of Egyptian subjects and scenes, there are 71 of other locations, primarily European and American.

did.unittitle: Egypt views, labeled with numbers EgyV7_001 - EgyV7_040, missing #19
Egypt views, labeled with numbers EgyV7_0041 - EgyV7_0114

Numbered set of views by T. W. Ingersoll, of street scenes, building views, interiors, landscapes in the US, Mexico, Europe, Algiers, Egypt, and elsewhere, all printed with green card background and a description on the reverse (71 items), 1890s
Cairo as represented in American world fairs (4 views), and views of Cairo (2), 1893-1894
Stereo viewer tool
Series III: Postcards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains 315 postcards of Egyptian scenes and subjects. 157 are loose, 152 are in labeled sets ranging in size from 4 to 24, and 6 are larger than standard size.

did.unittitle: Postcards grouped at EgyV5, generally of Cairo scenes
Postcards grouped as EgyV6, generally Heliopolis
Loose postcards
Postcard sets, Egypt
Series IV: Printed travel guidebooks and souvenir programs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are 8 items in this series, the longest of which is an undated 9-3/16"x5-13/16" booklet of black and white photographs titled Souvenir of Cairo. Another of the items is a photograph-illustrataed engagement book style calendar titled Egypt 1958.

did.unittitle: Souvenir of Cairo booklet, published by the Cairo Postcard Trust, undated
Red booklet of Cairo and Egypt views, undated
Egypt calendar spiral bound booklet, 1958
"Street in Cairo: World's Columbian Exposition," booklet, 1893
A Brief Guide to Al-Haram Al-Sharif Jerusalem, published by the Supreme Moslem Council, 1924 and 1935
E. Tourjee's Educational Excursions to Europe, travel brochure, Boston, Mass., 1883
Series V: Souvenirs and ephemera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are 20 items in this series. 8 are short publications. 5 objects include a bronze commemorative medal; a pair of 45-rpm vinyl discs with Sono Cairo and Arabic writing on the jacket; 2 3"x5" fabric leaves, one with the Egyptian flag, and the other, "Abbas Hilmi, Khedive, Egypt"; a fringed silk "God Save the King" scarf; and an 8"x5" flannel Turkey-Egypt flag. The other 7 items include a United Arab Republic postage first day of issue cover from 1958, a bond certificate of the Land Bank of Egypt dated April 17, 1905, and a card game titled Egyptian Trivia.

did.unittitle: The Mameluke; or the Sign of the Mystic Tie, by B. Perley Poore, 1852
A Day with Royalty, B.C. 475, published 1901. Includes book dealer description.

The Mentor: Capetown to Cairo, Nov. 1922
L'Egyptienne, Revue Mensuelle, Politique - Feminisme - Sociologie - Art, Oct - Nov, 1926
The Egyptian Red Book, and The Irish Green Book, published by William Blackwood and Sons, 1880s

The Story of Some Old Friends, by George Pangalo

English / Arabic phrases and vocabulary
Notes Sur Un Texte Copte du XIIIe Siecle, par M. P. Casanova (unbound / uncut sigantures)
Bab-Zuweyla color lithograph, 1903
Egyptian flag and crest printed on silk, in New York (2)
Postal envelope from United Arab Republic featuring 50th Death Anniversary of Qasim Amin 1865-1908

Hand colored map of Cairo, A. H. Dufour, 1859
Engraved printed map of Cairo, Harper's Hand Book
Engraved map of Cairo, A. F. Dufour, undated
Color lithographs of Cairo Street, 1893 Chicago Exposition (2)
Series VI: Maps and oversize printed and photographic material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are 3 maps: an 1859 hand colored city map of Cairo; an 8-1/2"x11" black and white annotated map of Cairo; and a 7"x9" black and white annotated map of Cairo and the pyramids of Gizeh. 12 items are included among the oversize printed and photographic materials: 3 are color lithographs of Egyptian scenes. There are a fifteen-page portfolio of black and white photographs from the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition and a black and white page from Scientific American Nov. 16, 1895, with photos of the Atlanta Exposition. Also from the 1893 Columbian Exposition is a page of black and white photos of costumed participants. There are 3 sepia photographs of Cairo buildings. There are 2 large black and white photos on photographic paper, one of Cairo and pyramids from the air, and the other of the Midway and Tower in Streets of Cairo. Finally is the Oct. 1929 issue of Travel with the cover design titled "In Old Cairo."

did.unittitle: English and Egyptian fringed white silk textile souvenir of Egypt
